generalInfo:
Come join us on an incredible journey spanning two different worlds. Commencing your trip from Kolkata - the old seat of the British Raj near the Bay of Bengal - north to the mystical Land of the Thunder Dragon, our trip is sure to take you to a higher place as you climb from sea level into the Himalaya.

Along your journey you'll traverse the India-Bhutan frontier, breathe in the scents of Darjeelings incredible tea plantations, and find a magical world where trains are toys and monasteries are devoted to fertility. You might pinch yourself at the sight of the Punakha Valley rolling away beneath your feet or at spotting Asian elephants and one-horned rhino in their natural habitats.

As you take on this overland adventure, we've striven to put sustainable travel at the heart of what we do. By keeping our ecological footprint light, you'll get to intensify your experience in nature as the greens of the gorgeous Paro Valley stay green and the taste of lunch with a local Bhutanese family is more wholesome.

What’s not to love about a purely overland journey that shakes you awake in India, and ends in Bhutan by calming the soul in a hidden kingdom where economic development is measured in happiness?

Where We Take You:
Kolkata - Siliguri - Darjeeling - Gorumara National Park - Phuentsholing - Thimphu - Dochula Pass - Punakha - Paro

Activities:
Boat rides on the Hooghly - Sightseeing in Kolkata - UNESCO Toy train to Darjeeling - Sightseeing in Darjeeling - Tea Plantations - Land-crossing into Bhutan - Gorumara National Park - Sightseeing in Thimphu - Punakha Valley Temples - Trekking to Tiger's Nest Temple - Paro Valley

What's Included?
Accommodation / Trains / Road Transport / Airport Transfers / Guides & Escorts / Eating with Bhutanese family / Hotel & Lodges meals (from B&B to full board) / And much more.

dayInfo.description: Kolkata is where the fun begins. Upon arrival and check-in, what better way to get acquainted with India’s second city than a sunset boat ride on the river Hooghly?

We kick off the day with a city tour of Kolkata. Filled with sights that might astound you with an exotic feel of the familiar, this city tour will incorporate names closer to home, such as the iconic Victoria Memorial, Fort Williams, Esplanade, St. Paul's Cathedral, Potter's Village and College Street. End the day with coffee in one of Kolkata’s famous coffee houses. The evening you spend at your leisure.

Before a well-earned breakfast at an iconic local restaurant, get a taste for a different fragrance, by exploring Kolkata’s sprawling flower-market on the banks of the river Hooghly. After breakfast, it’s time to talk a stroll in and around Dalhousie Square to see a blend of heritage and pre-independence buildings. In the afternoon you will visit the vegetable and spice market, and then we put theory into practice with lunch at a Bengali family home. Again, your evening is at leisure.

Today is a travel day. An early morning transfer to Howrah railway station will find us connecting with the all-new Vande Bharat train to New Jalpaiguri. The Vande Bharat stands as one of the finest short-haul trains on India’s vast rail network. The service departs Howrah at 05:55, reaching New Jalpaiguri at 13:25. Meals served onboard. Transfer to your hotel in Siliguri. In the afternoon, take in the sights and sounds at your leisure.

Following breakfast, we take the narrow gauge toy-train from New Jalpaiguri to Darjeeling. Enjoy the experience of winding up the foothills of the Himalaya. This UNESCO Heritage train ride starts its slow ascent at 10:00, reaching Darjeeling at 17:30. Packed lunch shall be provided. Transfer to hotel and evening to relax.

Today sees a marked shift in our itinerary, in both altitude and feel of the overall experience. Its name forever synonymous with tea, today will be your first day in one of India’s most well-known hill stations. Our visit takes in the Himalayan Mountaineering Institute, Zoological park, Mall road, and local market.

Today we take the iconic steam toy train to Ghoom monastery. A journey through this high country would be incomplete without seeing at first hand the tea plantations that lent Darjeeling its fame. This educational tour includes tasting, leaf-plucking and the other various process involved in producing export-quality tea. You’ll lunch on the estate before returning by evening to your hotel.

After breakfast, we drive through the gateway to the dooars: Chalsa. In this frontier space between North East India and Bhutan, we’ll spend the afternoon on safari at Gorumara National Park. There the one-horned Indian rhino and Asian elephant can be observed at close quarter.

Today we cross the border. After breakfast, private transport will deliver you safely to the India-Bhutan border (2 hours) and complete the visa formalities. Our trip takes us on a spectacular ascent through gorgeous Himayalan scenery towards Thimphu (4 hours) with lunch en-route. The evening is set aside for a leisurely stroll through Thimphu.

Commencing our first full day in the ‘land of the thunder dragon’, we launch into a fulfilling morning schedule, which includes Buddha Dordenma, the Postal Museum, and the Textile Museum. After lunch, we shall visit the centenary farmers market, Zilkha nunnery, and the Pangri Zampa monastery. We end the day with a visit to Trashichhoedzong.

Today we move towards Punakha Valley. En route, we aim to cross the 3088mt Dochu-la (pass). The distance between Thimphu & Punakha is about 80 Kms and will take around 3 hours. Reward your getting there with an afternoon of leisure.

After breakfast, we explore on foot the administrative capital of the region, the Punakha Dzong. Later we visit Chimi Lakhang - also know as the temple of fertility. This afternoon you are invited to take a 2hr comfortable hike to Khamsum Yuelley Namgel Chorten. Personal effort brings great reward, as you’ll see from the top, with outstanding views of the entire Punakha valley.
Today involves a drive back towards Thimphu and further on to Paro [115 Kms / 4 Hours]. The afternoon will be well spent visiting Ta Dzong and Rinpung Dzong. Evning at leisure.

The day starts with a fascinating excursion to Taktshang Monastery, famously known as the Tiger's Nest. Reaching the monastery, sitting about 900m above the Paro valley, takes no more than 5 hours and back on foot. On return we shall drop into a Bhutanese farm house for lunch. The rest of the day is at your leisure to explore Paro centre.
All good things must come to an end. Transfer to airport and fly from Paro, either to Kolkata, Delhi or Kathmandu. Connect with your onward flight home or extend in either India or Nepal.

tourName: Best of Nepal and Bhutan holiday
generalInfo:
Embark on an unforgettable adventure with our "Best of Nepal and Bhutan with Poon Hill Hike" tour, a journey that combines the spiritual and cultural richness of Nepal and Bhutan with the breathtaking landscapes of the Himalayas. This comprehensive tour offers an immersive experience into the heart of two of the world's most enchanting destinations, complete with a rewarding hike to the famous Poon Hill.

Begin your journey in Nepal, where you will explore the vibrant city of Kathmandu. Visit the ancient Swayambhunath Stupa (Monkey Temple) and the magnificent Bouddhanath Stupa, both UNESCO World Heritage Sites. Discover the architectural wonders of Patan and Bhaktapur, where centuries-old palaces and temples tell stories of the rich history and culture of the Kathmandu Valley.

Next, venture into the serene landscapes of Pokhara, a city known for its tranquil lakes and stunning mountain views. Here, embark on the iconic Poon Hill hike. This trek takes you through lush forests, charming villages, and terraced fields, culminating in a sunrise view from Poon Hill that will leave you speechless. Witness the sun cast a golden glow over the peaks of Annapurna and Dhaulagiri, one of the most awe-inspiring sights in the Himalayas.

After experiencing the natural beauty of Nepal, fly to the Kingdom of Bhutan, where the ancient traditions and pristine landscapes create a unique and mystical atmosphere. Start in Paro with a visit to the iconic Tiger's Nest Monastery, perched precariously on a cliffside. Continue to Thimphu, the capital city, where you will explore the majestic Tashichho Dzong, the National Memorial Chorten, and the bustling markets.

Travel to Punakha, the ancient capital of Bhutan, and visit the stunning Punakha Dzong, located at the confluence of two rivers. Take a peaceful hike to Chimi Lhakhang, the temple of the Divine Madman, and enjoy the serene beauty of the Bhutanese countryside.

Throughout your journey, you will stay in comfortable accommodations, enjoy delicious local cuisine, and be accompanied by knowledgeable guides who will enrich your experience with their insights and stories.

The "Best of Nepal and Bhutan with Poon Hill Hike" tour is a perfect blend of cultural exploration, spiritual discovery, and natural beauty. Whether you are a seasoned traveler or a first-time visitor, this tour promises to leave you with unforgettable memories and a deep appreciation for the wonders of Nepal and Bhutan. Join us on this extraordinary journey and discover the magic of the Himalayas.

dayInfo.description: ARRIVAL: At the arrival section of Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, one of our representatives will be waiting to welcome you. The airport representative will explain the program upon arrival and escort you to the hotel on a private vehicle. Overnight in Kathmandu; Meals: welcome dinner

KATHMANDU HERITAGE SITE TOUR: After breakfast, Kathmandu tour starts. Kathmandu valley is the capital of the country and home to 7 UNESCO World Heritage Sites. It is an incredibly diverse city with a breathtaking Newari culture, centuries-old Hindu and Buddhists cultural sites alongside a plethora of ancient monuments. Throughout the day, we will visit most of the UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Kathmandu. Overnight stay at the hotel;

DRIVE TO POKHARA: Today, we drive through beautiful villages and landscapes to Pokhara. After approximately 8-10 hrs of drive, we reach the beautiful lake city Pokhara. Upon reaching Pokhara, take a walk along the lake and stretch your legs. Overnight stay at the hotel; Meals: B

TREK TO TIKHEDHUNGA (5hrs): After breakfast, we drive towards Nayapul. From there, we start our trek to Poonhill. Passing through the Modi Khola and dense forest of rhododendrons and oak, we reach Tikhedunga. Overnight in Tikhedhunga; Meals: B, L, D

TREK TO GHOREPANI (6hrs): Continuing our path below and climbing uphill we will reach Ulleri. Again, from there, we will go through the Magar village by viewing the beautiful mountain and reach the Ghorepani. Ghorepani is a beautiful village from where we can see the mountain views of Dhaulagiri, Annapurna South, Hiunchuli, Annapurna I and many other mountains. Overnight in Ghorepani; Meals: B, L, D

TREK TO GHANDRUK VIA POON HILL (7-8hrs): Early morning after breakfast we head for Poonhill. Poonhill is often famous for the mesmerizing views of sunrise and sunsets over incredible range of high Himalayas such as Dhaulagiri (8167m), Annapurna I (8091m), Annapurna II (7937m), Annapurna III (7855m), Annapurna IV (7525m), Annapurna South (7219m), Nilgiri (6940m), Tukuche (6920m), Varaha Shikhar (7847m), LamjungHimal (6931m) and many more. We rest atPoonhill for a while and continue our journey. After about 3 hours of walk through the alpine forest of oaks, rhododendron and others, we reach Ghandruk which is the largest Gurung village rich in its authentic culture and tradition. This village also offers the scenic views of Annapurna South, Gangapurna, Machhapuchhre, Annapurna III, Hiunchuli and other mountains from the viewpoint. Overnight at Ghandruk; Meals: B, L, D

POKHARA: This is the last day of our trek in Annapurna Region. From Ghandruk, today, we leave for Pokhara through the descend trail including the views of alluring mountains. We cross through the forest of blooming rhododendron and reach Birethanti from where we walk down hill and follow Modi Khola to reach Nayapul. Resting for a while, from there, we head to Pokhara which will take us about an hour of drive. In the evening after reaching Pokhara, we stay at the same hotel. If time permits, we go for an evening walk or try cycling around the Lake Side of Pokhara. We stay overnight at Pokhara tonight; Meals: B

KATHMANDU: After 8-10 hours’ drive, we will reach the heart of the country where the necessary preparation for the departure day will be carried out. Visit Thamel for a shopping on your own. If time is sufficient, we will be preparing a small farewell get-together. Overnight stay at the hotel; Meals: B

FLY TO PARO, DRIVE TO THIMPU: Depending on your flight time you will be transferred to the airport. The flight to Paro is one of the most spectacular mountain flights in the world, providing a spectacular panorama of some of the highest mountains on earth. After lunch, we will enjoy sightseeing at Paro, visiting the Ta Dzong Museum which shelters a lot of religious relics, works of art and handicrafts providing great insight on Bhutan’s historical, cultural, and religious past. Next, we visit the Rimpong Dzongand observe the painting of the great saint Milarepa, considered the master of meditation by the Bhutanese. Afterwards, we drive to the capital, Thimphu along the Pachu River. Overnight at your hotel in Thimphu; Meals: B, L, D

THIMPHU: Enjoy a full day of sightseeing at the bustling capital of Bhutan - Thimpu. We will visit the National Memorial Chorten, first initiated by the Third King in order to protect from negative impacts of modernization, and a monument of world peace. The Royal Queen Mother later completed it to commemorate the Third King who passed away in 1972. Next, we continue towards 12th-century Changangkha Temple and Drubthob monastery housing the Zilukha Nunnery. Furthermore, we will also visit the School for Arts and Crafts where students are taught the 13 types of Bhutanese art, The National Library which has wide collections of Bhutanese scriptures dating back to the 8th century, the Traditional Paper Factory displaying the Bhutanese paper making process, and a fascinating replica of a medieval farmhouse at the Folk Heritage Museum. In the remaining time, we can also explore the nursing pen for the Takin, the national animal of Bhutan, and Tashichhodzong, ‘the fortress of the glorious religion’. If your visit to Thimphu falls on the weekend, you can stroll through the Thimphu Marketand observe the variety of foods of Bhutan, including a basket of fiery chillies, cheese and a variety of greens. (This market is open only on Friday-Sunday). Overnight at your hotel in Thimphu. Meals: B, L, D

THIMPHU – PUNAKHA: Today we drive over the Dochu-La pass (3,100 meters), which offers an incredible view of Himalayan peaks on a clear day before descending to Punakha valley (about 3 hrs drive). At Punakha, we visit Punakha Dzong, also known as Punakha Dzong (meaning “the palace of great happiness or bliss”), built-in 1637 by the Shabdrung, the ‘Unifier of Bhutan.’ It is the ancient capital of Bhutan and now the winter headquarters of the Je Khenpo. The three-story main temple of the Punakha Dzong is a breathtaking example of traditional architecture with four intricately embossed entrance pillars crafted from cypress and decorated in gold and silver. Observing the administrative and cultural centre for a while, we advance towards Chimi Lhakhang en-route to Wangdiphodrang (dzong built-in 1638). Overnight at your hotel in Punakha/ Wangduephodrang. Meals: B, L, D

PUNAKHA – THIMPHU – PARO: In the morning, we drive to Yabesa village and hike to through ricefields and up to KhamsumYueley Namgyal Chorten, built by her majesty the queen Ashi Tshering Yangdon Wangchuk. Next, we explore WangduephodrangDzong. We then drive back to Thimpu and proceed to Paro, and visit Semtokha Dzongen route. The Dzong, built-in 1627, is the oldest in Bhutan. It is now the Institute for Language and Culture studies. Overnight at your hotel in Paro. Meals: B, L, D

HIKE TO TIGER’S NEST: After breakfast, we hike towards the Taktsang Monastery which takes about 3 -4 hrs to reach there. The Monastery is an important pilgrim site for the Buddhists. As per the legends, the great Guru Rimpoche and his consort meditated in a cave here for three months after he brought the teachings of the Buddhist Dharma to Bhutan in the 8th Century. After meditation, they turned themselves in the forms of Guru DorjiDrolo and a tigress to defeat the demons in the valley below. The cave, where the monastery was later built is thought to be the origin of Buddhism in Bhutan. In the afternoon, we drive to the ruins of the 17th Century Drukgyel Dzong, an historic monument built by the Shabdrung to commemorate his victory over Tibetans in 1644. We then return to Paro and visit 7th Century Kyichu Lhakhang, one of the 108 temples constructed by the Tibetan king SongtsenGampo. Overnight at your hotel in Paro. Meals: B, L, D
DEPART PARO: Depending on your flight time, you will be transferred to the airport for your onward destination. Until next time! Meals: B

placesVisited: Paro, Taksang Monastery, Bumthang, Tang Valley, Phobjikha Valley, Trongsa Dzong, Punakha Valley, Punakha Dzong, Thimphu Valley, Haa Valley, Guided hikes, bike rides and rafting
generalInfo:
This tailor-made activity holiday in Bhutan perfectly blends cultural discovery with adventure, offering moderate hill hikes, scenic cycling routes, and exhilarating rafting—all set against the breathtaking landscapes and rich spiritual heritage of the Himalayan Kingdom.

Your journey will take you through lush green valleys, golden paddy fields, and dense forests that support the lives of many Bhutanese communities. Knowledgeable and friendly local guides will ensure every step of your trip is smooth and meaningful, deepening your understanding of the region and its people.

Cycling in the Himalayas can be a gentle challenge, but the routes are carefully chosen for travelers with reasonable fitness. Gradual climbs and manageable distances make each ride both enjoyable and rewarding—after all, this is your holiday!

Hiking in Bhutan is equally memorable, with trails leading to iconic sites such as Taksang (Tiger’s Nest) Monastery and Lungchu Zeka Monastery. These walks offer spectacular views and the chance to visit some of the Kingdom’s most sacred shrines. The climb to Tiger’s Nest is a highlight for many, as is exploring Bumthang, the spiritual heart of Bhutan, with its serene valleys, ancient temples, and centuries-old monasteries.

Midway through your adventure, you’ll cross the striking suspension bridge in Punakha Valley and enjoy a morning of river rafting. While some sections are a bit more energetic, much of the experience allows for gentle paddling, giving you time to soak in the scenery. Afterward, a catered riverside lunch awaits on a sandbar, followed by a visit to Punakha Dzong, one of Bhutan’s most magnificent fortified monasteries.

What truly sets this journey apart is the quiet serenity of Bhutan’s trails. Thanks to the Kingdom’s sustainable tourism policies, many destinations feel untouched and peaceful. Your local guides will help you connect with the villages, providing insight into life in these remote, tranquil communities.

dayInfo.description: Welcome to Bhutan | Short Bike Ride | Paro Dzong | Paro Drugyal Dzong : Arrive at Bhutan’s Paro International Airport, surrounded by a beautiful mountain view. A short shuttle will take you to the bike fitting location, where you will have a safety briefing, enjoy lunch, and start your first bike ride in Bhutan. The ride will begin with smooth, gentle roads, passing stunning views of cultural landmarks like Paro Dzong, the national museum on the hillside, and the town of Paro. The route follows the clear Paro Chhu River, surrounded by rice fields and mountains, as you head toward Drugyal Dzong. This stands as a reminder of Bhutan;s history despite its destruction in 1950. After exploring the ruins, you will ride back to the hotel. Duration: 2-3 hours of gradual ascents and descents. Distance: 16- 23 km Difficulty: Easy to Moderate ** Note: Van support is available every day, with options for different riding distances.

TIGER'S NEST HIKE | Hot Stone Bath: Today, we hike to one of Bhutan's most sacred sites, the Tiger's Nest Monastery, or Taksang, perched on a cliffside. This place is a must-visit for anyone coming to Bhutan and a key pilgrimage spot for locals. The temple complex seems to hang on the mountainside, offering a peaceful environment for meditation. The trail is wide and gradually climbs above the valley, offering stunning views below. At 9,200 feet, we reach our destination and enter this sacred space, where prayer flags flutter in the wind. A tour through the chapels and stories of the past helps us understand the significance of the Tiger's Nest. After descending, we return to the hotel for lunch and an afternoon with options—enjoy a spa, shop in Paro, or try archery. Walking duration: 4-5 hours Distance: 6 km Difficulty: Moderate to Strenuous.

Bumthang Spiritual Heartland | Explore Bumthang on Bike: This morning, we take a short 35-minute flight to Bumthang, located in the center of Bhutan. Known for its four peaceful valleys, it’s often called the "Switzerland" of Bhutan. As soon as we land, you’ll feel that you’ve arrived in a unique and timeless place. The landscape is filled with temples and monasteries, and the town holds a calm spiritual energy. We’ll explore the area by bike, visiting various temple sites and religious compounds, including Jambay Lhakhang, Jakar Dzong, Wangdichholing Palace, and the impressive Kurjay Lhakhang. Duration: 3-6 hours Distance: to be confirmed Difficulty: Easy ** Note: Van support is available every day, with options for different riding distances.

Tang Valley | Traditional Way of Living : Today, in Bumthang's Tang Valley, we offer different biking routes with a hike to explore the valley’s mystical and legendary sites. The bike ride takes us through small villages and spiritual landmarks, crossing from one valley to another. The ride ends at the start of our hike into the historic Tang Valley, where we’ll visit the "flaming lake" and enjoy lunch at the old palace museum. Life here is simpler, with basic structures and a more traditional way of living. This valley reflects the authentic lifestyle of much of the country. Duration: 5-6 hours Difficulty: Easy- Moderate Distance: 30-60 km ** Note: Van support is available every day, with options for different riding distances.

Phobjikha Gangtey | Chendebji Chorten: After two nights in the spiritual heart of Bhutan, we begin our journey west to explore the beautiful Phobjikha Valley. This peaceful and less-visited valley is home to the small village of Gangtey, located on the western slopes of the Black Mountains. The valley, a protected conservation area, is also the winter home of the endangered black-necked cranes. Our ride begins at a stunning viewpoint near Trongsa Dzong, with views of Chendebji Chorten, a stupa built in the style of the Monkey Temple in Kathmandu. We’ll ride through wide valleys toward Pele La pass, where there’s a good chance of spotting monkeys. Our final destination is beyond the pass, but there is an option to take a van shuttle to the hotel. Duration: 6-7 hours Difficulty: Moderate-Strenuous (with a shuttle over the pass) **Today can also be a more relaxed day with extra time at the hotel and to enjoy the beautiful surroundings.

Punakha | Lawa La Pass | Punakha Valley: The bike ride begins at Lawa La pass, gradually descending into the Punakha valley. As we ride through ridges and valleys with forests and clear streams, the temperature warms up, and the landscape becomes more tropical. At 5,000 feet, Punakha welcomes us with the sight of the majestic Wangdi Dzong and the glacial waters of the Punakha River. The valley is rich and fertile, with rice crops grown twice a year. We ride along the river, enjoying the fresh scenery and warm weather as we head toward the hotel.

Rafting the Pho Chhu River | Punakha Dzong | Punakha Valley : We start our day at the hotel spring lot and head towards the river, making our way to where the Mo Chhu and Pho Chhu rivers meet. After crossing a beautiful suspension bridge, we continue up the Pho Chhu to meet our rafting guides and hop into the rafts for an exciting ride to our lunch stop. Tents await us on a sandbar, where we enjoy a catered lunch with views of the Punakha Dzong, one of Bhutan’s most stunning landmarks. After lunch, we explore the inside of the Dzong, seeing where royal ceremonies like coronations and weddings take place, and where hundreds of monks live, Duration: 2 hours of riding bike, 1.5 hours of rafting Difficulty: Easy- Moderate Riding Distance: 15 km

Thimphu | Dochula Pass | Lungchu Tse Monastery: Today, we will travel from Punakha to Thimphu, passing through Dochu La Pass at 10,000 feet. At the top, 108 religious Chortens stand in honor of the king’s contributions to the country’s stability and progress. The area is filled with prayer flags fluttering in the wind. From here, we will hike through a forest of moss-covered trees and rhododendrons to Lungchu Zeka Monastery, following the same route the Queen Mother takes annually. If the weather is clear, we’ll enjoy a 360-degree view of the Bhutanese Himalayas. Continuing along the ridge, we will visit a meditation nunnery and quietly pass through the alleys and courtyards leading to the valley below. We’ll arrive in Thimphu in the late afternoon, where there may be some time for shopping before dinner. Duration: 4-5 hours of hiking Difficulty: Moderate-Strenuous

Thimphu Valley Exploration | Big Buddha | Cheri Goemba: We begin by driving up above Thimphu to see one of the largest Buddha statues in the world, standing 169 feet tall and housing 100,000 smaller Buddhas inside. From there, we’ll bike down the hillside, passing through back roads with views of the city, Parliament, the King’s offices, and two royal palaces. When we reach the end of the valley, we’ll leave our bikes and hike to Cheri Goempa. Built in 1620, it’s one of Bhutan’s most sacred places, where the first monk settled. The forested hike may offer glimpses of monkeys and wild goats, and the ancient route through the monastery feels timeless. Lunch will be in a meadow below, where you can also try your hand at darts, Bhutan’s national sport. Sitting by the Wang Chu, you’ll see one of the clearest rivers you’ve ever encountered. Afterward, you can choose to take the shuttle back to town, where you can enjoy a spa or explore the city. Duration: 2 hours biking, 2 hours hiking Biking Distance: Approx. 22 km Difficulty: Moderate

Bike Ride at Haa | Last night in Paro : This memorable day of biking starts in the Haa Valley, a place that opened to visitors just four years ago. The ride takes you through untouched forests, farmed lands, and stunning views on smooth roads. The thrill comes from knowing that few people have experienced this route. The day includes a few challenging climbs but plenty of enjoyable downhills, one of which is 7 km long! A picnic lunch is served along the way, and the ride finishes by the confluence of two rivers, following the Paro Chhu back to the valley where we began our journey 10 days ago. There's time to appreciate the beautiful location of the hotel before our final night, with a cocktail gathering and dinner to look forward to. Duration: 4-5 hours Distance: 48 km.

Departure: This is a personalized, private tour that can be curated to your liking – whether you’re a solo traveler, part of a family, or with a group of friends. We’re happy to adjust the activities, pace, and duration to match your interests and schedule. This is your trip, your way!

placesVisited: Paro, Thimpu, Gangtey, Bumthan, Chokhor Valley, Tang Valley homestay, Punakha, Tiger's Nest Monastery
generalInfo:
This two week tour of Bhutan goes some way to unlocking the cultural, scenic and spiritual secrets of one of Asia's most mysterious and enticing countries.

As part of a small group you'll get to experience the mountain passes, valley floors and precariously placed monasteries that have long been out of reach to all but the Bhutanese.

A series of guided hikes and treks, and a couple of long drives, help to create an ever-changing scenic backdrop with farm visits and overnight homestays further developing your understanding of Bhutan and her people.

Fortified dzongs and Buddhist monasteries also provide travellers with ample opportunities to discover lifestyles very far removed from their own as well as offering superior viewing platforms from where to take in some of Asia's most stunning and lesser-known scenes.

Walking trails in central Bhutan lead through vast agricultural landscapes and peaceful rural settings where prayer flags flutter in the breeze and gentle folk bid visitors a warm welcome, not without a touch of friendly curiosity.

Wherever possible, small group itineraries will aim to coincide with cultural festivals which tend to take place around Bhutan's dzongs. If you're interested in finding out dates for local festivities then please get in touch or check individual departure dates accordingly.

dayInfo.description: Tour starts in Paro: Thimphu: On arrival at Paro airport (see GETTING THERE section below), we will be met and transferred to Thimphu, Bhutan’s capital, approximately one hour away. Although the Thimphu Valley has supported small settlements for many centuries and a dzong has existed there since 1216, the city didn't really develop until the King declared Thimphu the new capital in 1961. Thimphu has a youthful exuberance that constantly challenges the country’s conservatism and proud tradition. The ever-present juxtaposition of old and new is just one of its appealing qualities, and today, it is Bhutan’s most modern and developed city. On arrival in Thimphu, there will be some free time to settle in and relax after an introductory briefing.

In Thimphu: Explore Thimphu: We have a whole day to explore the capital. We'll visit the National Memorial Chorten, dedicated to the third King of Bhutan and a pilgrimage site for the older generation of Bhutanese people. Then, we'll visit the Buddha Dordenma statue overlooking Thimphu valley, before enjoying a short hike (approx. 5km) in Kuensel Phodrang National Park and paying a visit to Takin Park to try to see Bhutan's national animal. After lunch, we'll visit the Simply Bhutan Living Museum and the Post Office, an unusual and enjoyable visit as it displays and sells a wide range and style of philately. If time permits, we'll visit a local market and enjoy a stroll through town.

Thimphu - Gangtey: Journey over Donchu La Pass: This morning, we leave the capital city behind us and head over the Dochu La Pass, which stands at 3140m. If the weather is kind to us, we will be greeted with a panoramic view of the Himalayas with a hill of 108 chortens in front of us. Here, we will also visit the newest temple built in Bhutan with wall paintings of monks using laptops, aeroplanes, mobile phones, and satellite dishes. The winding road will continue through mountain forests, taking us on to Gangtey in the Phobjikha Valley, our destination for the next couple of nights.

In Gangtey: Walk in Phobjikha Valley: Today, we will take a hike in the Phobjikha Valley starting near Gangtey Monastery. We will stroll gently uphill and visit the charming local villages of Gophu, Dogsena Pana and Jangchub Lhakhang, taking in some traditional old village life in a rural and agricultural part of the country, surrounded by beautiful landscapes. From here, we will start to descend, completing the circuit towards the village of Khewa Lhakhang. If time permits, in the evening, we may have time to visit the Buddhist College and participate in evening prayer. During the winter months from late October to mid-February, we may have the opportunity to see black-necked cranes in the valley.Hiking in the Phobjikha Valley: Approximate Distance - 8km. Time - 4 hours

Gangtey - Bumthang: Trongsa dzong and Chumey Yathra weaving centre: We’ll drive to Bumthang today via Trongsa, where we will stop for lunch and visit the dzong. In the afternoon, we’ll continue to Bumthang, stopping en route at the Chumey Yathra textile and weaving centre before checking into our hotel.

Chokhor Valley: Walk to Tamshing Lakhang: After breakfast, we will have a short drive to Kharsumphe village before beginning our gradual ascent on foot to Tamshing Lakhang, with good views of Kurje Lhakhang on the other side of the Chamkhar River. We will enjoy lunch at a local farmhouse and will hopefully have the chance to try Bhutan's national sport, archery, and khuru with the local community. Returning to our hotel after lunch, we may have time to wander along the main street of Jakar and have tea in one of the local cafes before visiting Wangdicholing Museum Palace in the afternoon.Walking Chokhor Valley & Tamshing Lakhang: Approximate Distance - 5km. Time - 1 1/2 hours

Chokhor Valley - Tang Valley: View from Batela Pass: Today's hike starts above the private Buddhist Monastery of Kharchu and through pastures with beautiful views onto Jakar Valley. Traversing through a pine forest, we'll reach 3,100m atop Batela Pass. Here, we'll enjoy the most stunning panoramic vista of the Tang Valley, our home for the next few nights. After taking it all in, we'll start our descent to Bapzur Village, where we will visit a nunnery and have a chat with some local nuns if we're lucky. Continuing by vehicle, we will enjoy a farmhouse lunch before visiting the Ogyen Choling Palace Museum. We'll be transported back to 19th- and 20th-century living through the intricate recreations of granaries, homes, and the like. Back at the homestay, there will be plenty of time to rejuvenate in a hot stone bath followed by a glass of locally brewed ara.Hiking in Tang Valley & Batela Pass: Approximate Distance - 9-10km. Time - 3 hours

In the Tang Valley: Hike to Thowadra Monastery: We have a good hike today, which is both challenging and rewarding, to the revered and sacred site of Thowadra Monastery. The name means ‘highest rock’ and stands at an altitude of 3400m. It was blessed by the presence of Guru Rinpoche, who meditated here and left his footprints in the stone. The walk itself starts from the north end of the Tang Valley, at 2750m on a dirt road along the riverside until it crosses the river by a wooden bridge. The trail starts to climb up before a short descent and crossing another bridge. Upon reaching a chorten, the trail again ascends through pine forest and past several monuments in the mountainside. For the last section, the trail is very steep, with the monastery hanging above you on the cliff, motivating you to climb the last stone steps to the top. From here, we will enjoy the fabulous view of the Tang Valley on the horizon and visit the mysterious and exceptionally holy temple, which is built directly into the cliff walls. We will then retrace our steps down to the first bridge, where our host will be waiting with a hot picnic and a cup of chai before returning to the delights of our homestay.Hiking in Tang Valley & Thowadra Monastery: Approximate Distance - 8km. Time - 4 hours

Tang Valley - Punakha: Chendebji Chorten and Pele La Pass: After breakfast, we’ll drive to Punakha, the old capital city, passing through Trongsa Valley. Along the way, we will make a quick stop at Chendebji Chorten, situated at a river confluence. Following this, we'll cross Pele La Pass at 3400m, before descending to the valley floor at 1200m and arriving in Punakha, the old capital of Bhutan before it was moved to Thimphu.

In Punakha: Khamsum Namgyal Chorten and Punakha Dzong: This morning, we take a beautiful walk up to the Khamsum Namgyal Chorten, a small temple built for the present King by his mother. Wandering back down through the villages and along the riverbank takes us through an idyllic rural setting. Later, we’ll visit Punakha Dzong, spectacularly positioned at the confluence of two thundering rivers and noted for its huge prayer hall with three giant Buddhas and wonderful painted thangkas. Hiking Khamsun Namgyai Chorten: Approximate Distance - 6km. Time - 2 hours

Punakha - Paro: The Divine Madman's Temple and Paro Dzong: Today, we will retrace our steps and head for Paro – the starting point of our journey in Bhutan. But first, we will have an early morning visit to the famous Divine Madman’s Temple, or Chime Lhakhang, in the beautifully tranquil Lobesa Valley. Arriving in Paro late afternoon, we can visit Paro Dzong, built in 1644 under the order of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal. Paro Dzong’s full name is Rinpung Dzong, which means ‘the fortress of the heap of jewels’. It is one of the finest examples of Bhutanese architecture and contains fourteen shrines. To end the day, there will be time to further explore Paro at leisure.

In Paro: Tiger's Nest Monastery: This morning we will walk up to the Takstang Gompa, known as the Tiger’s Nest Monastery, standing at 3010m. Along the way, we will stop at the monastery viewpoint for the photo-perfect view of the monastery. stopping en route at the viewpoint and teahouse to which we will return for lunch. This is without doubt the most spectacular monastery in Bhutan, built on a rock ledge a thousand metres above the valley floor. The first and main temple was built where Guru Rinpoche is said to have flown on the back of a tiger to meditate in this cave on a rocky ledge. The hike to the viewing point takes about 1.5 hours along a mountain trail with steep sections. After the viewpoint, it is another 1.5-hour hike to get to the monastery, including a short descent followed by a few hundred steps. In the afternoon, there is an opportunity to visit our last Bhutanese temple, Kyichu Lhakhang, an auspicious 8th-century temple built over the left foot of a mythical demoness who had been preventing the spread of Buddhism over Tibet and the whole of the Himalayas. This evening, we will celebrate our achievements and enjoy our final group dinner of the tour.Hiking Takstang Gompa (Tiger's Nest Monastery): Approximate Distance - 7km. Time - 5 hours

Tour ends in Paro: The tour ends this morning in Paro after breakfast. Depending on your flight departure time, there may be an opportunity for some last-minute souvenir shopping and a wander through Paro before transferring to the airport.

generalInfo:
This tour is specially tailored to provide the best of Bhutan’s and Nepal's timeless culture and traditions. You will experience Bhutan’s unique rich culture with visits to beautiful fortresses, museums and visits to farmhouses, experience local cuisine, relaxing hot stone bath after a tiring day, hike up to the famous

Taktshang Monastery popularly known as Tiger’s nest. Travel between lush green valleys’ to dense forest. Discover some of the most sacred Buddhist monasteries, temples and marvel at the ancient paintings and carvings in fortress and temples.
You will visit all 7 UNESCO World Heritage sites in Kathmandu Valley to feel the core of Nepal, culture and history.
If you're short on time, then this tour is definitely for you!
***
Price includes in Bhutan:
• Carefully selected 3* hotel accommodation;
• Deluxe room with twin sharing basis;
• Personal specialized licensed English speaking guide & driver;
• Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner (excluding alcoholic drinks & soft drinks);
• Excellent SUV for transportation throughout the tour;
• All entrance fees & sightseeing including Monasteries & Dzongs/fortress etc.;
• Bhutan Government daily royalties, and other taxes;
• Tea, Snacks and Mineral water all time during the tour.
In Nepal:
• 2-nights’ accommodation in Kathmandu in a 3-star hotel with breakfast on a twin sharing basis;
• Sightseeing on a private vehicle with an English speaking guide in Kathmandu during Day 1 and Day 2;
• Airport transfers on Day 1 and Day 3;
• Welcome dinner;
• All taxes.
***
Price excludes:
• lunches and dinners in Kathmandu;
• International flights to Nepal and Bhutan;
• visa fee to Nepal ($30); Bhutan ($40)
• travel insurance;
• entrance fees during sightseeing in Kathmandu
• bills of personal nature;
• tips for guides and drivers.

dayInfo.description: ARRIVAL PLUS SIGHTSEEING Upon arrival, our representatives will be at the Tribhuvan international airport to welcome and escort you to the hotel. We then head out for Kathmandu sightseeing. Capital of the country, Kathmandu is home to 7 UNESCO world heritage sites. Throughout the day we will visit some of the heritage sites. Sights to visit: Bouddhanath Stupa and Pashupatinath Temple. Overnight in Kathmandu.

KATHMANDU VALLEY SIGHTSEEING After breakfast, our full-day tour of the best-preserved cultural heritage sites begins. Our tour starts from the traditional city of Bhaktapur (UNESCO World Heritage Site), then heads towards the oldest city of Kirtipur, and ends with the visit to the major attractions of the historical city Patan (UNESCO World Heritage Site). Overnight in Kathmandu.

ARRIVE PARO – THIMPHU (1-hour drive) The flight to Paro is one of the most spectacular mountain flights in the world, with a constantly changing panorama of some of the highest mountains on earth. Arrive at Paro and drive to Thimphu. Depending on the time of arrival, we'll go for sightseeing. Overnight in Thimphu;

THIMPHU VALLEY SIGHTSEEING After breakfast, visit the world’s tallest sitting Buddha statue at Buddha point which is 169 feet tall. After lunch visit Simply Museum, a “living” museum, Simply Bhutan is an initiative of the Bhutan Youth Development Fund that aims to increase young Bhutanese people's engagement with their traditional culture. Later visit Painting School the Institute offers you a glimpse of novices learning 13 traditional arts and crafts of Bhutan. Visit the traditional paper making factory. Overnight in Thimphu;

THIMPHU TO PUNAKHA VALLEY (2 hours’ drive) Today after breakfast you will drive to Punakha (1300m/4265ft) the former capital of Bhutan. On the way after 45 minutes? drive from Thimphu will reach the highest pass between Thimphu and Punakha the place called Dochula pass (3140m). One can see many snow-covered 7000 meter peaks, including Gangkhar Phuensum, the world's highest unclimbed mountain. Gasa Dzong also appears in the distance. Upon reaching Punakha valley visit Punakha Dzong the impressive Dzong built-in 1637 by Shabdrung Ngawang Namgyal to serve as the religious and administrative centre of the region. After visiting the Punakha Dzong take a leisurely walk for 5 to 10 minutes to reach the longest suspension bridge of Bhutan. We have a great view of villages on the other side of the river. Overnight in Punakha;

PHOBJIKHA VALLEY TOUR 2.5 hours’ drive Today after breakfast drive towards Phobjikha Valley. On arrival, visit Gangtey Goempa, the oldest Nyingmapa temple in western Bhutan. Gangtey Goemba sits on the crest of a hill, overlooking majestic views of the Phobjikha Valley. Quite appropriately, its name means simply “the temple on the hilltop. Then explore the valley on foot is the best way to experience Gangtey as you will walk by small villages and picturesque scenery. Later visit Crane Information Centre which gives all the information about birds. Do the Nature Trail hike which is around 2 km to enjoy the valley and meet with the locals and enjoy the fresh lush green vegetation all around Bhutan. Overnight in Punakha;

PUNAKHA TO PARO (2 hours’ drive) After early breakfast, drive back to Paro, upon reaching Paro visit National Museum and the Ringpung Dzong. Later visit Kyichu temple, one of the oldest temples in Bhutan which was built in the 7th century, and in the evening stroll around the main street for some interesting Himalayan artefacts or textiles or have a relaxing stay in the hotel. Overnight in Paro;

HIKE TO TIGER’S NEST After breakfast hike to Taktsang Monastery. The walk of approximately 1.5 to 2 hours uphill takes you almost a kilometre above the Paro valley floor (for those who cannot hike we will arrange a horse for transfer up to cafeteria). From a distance, Bhutan's most iconic building seems to float, weightless, halfway up a sheer cliff-face, 900 meters (3,000 feet) above the floor of the Paro Valley. Later in the evening enjoy a relaxing hot stone bath to relax your sore muscles after the hike (extra charges applicable). Overnight in Paro;
DEPART PARO Breakfast in the hotel, then drive to the airport for a flight to your onward destination. Tashi Delek !

generalInfo:
This exclusive Bhutan-Nepal Cultural Tour brings you into the heart of two of the Himalaya’s most enchanting kingdoms. Rich in spirituality, cultural heritage, and natural beauty, both destinations offer experiences unlike anywhere else in the world.
Your journey begins in Kathmandu, a vibrant city filled with ancient temples, royal courtyards, sacred stupas, and bustling traditional markets. You will explore UNESCO World Heritage sites, visit revered Hindu and Buddhist temples, and discover the centuries-old craftsmanship found in the medieval cities of Bhaktapur and Patan.

The adventure continues as you fly to Bhutan, often described as the “Last Shangri-La” for its preserved traditions, peaceful landscapes, and deep-rooted spirituality. From the moment you land in Paro—surrounded by golden peaks and misty valleys-you’ll experience Bhutan’s unique culture, reflected in its monasteries, dzongs, prayer flags, and daily rituals. Explore the charming capital Thimphu, the serene former capital Punakha, the glacial valley of Phobjikha, and the historic treasures of Paro. A highlight of the tour is the iconic hike to Taktsang (Tiger’s Nest Monastery), perched dramatically on a cliffside 900 meters above the valley floor.

This journey is designed for travelers seeking cultural immersion, majestic Himalayan scenery, and meaningful encounters with local traditions. With a blend of sacred sites, heritage towns, and peaceful landscapes, this tour captures the timeless beauty and spiritual essence of Bhutan and Nepal.

dayInfo.description: Arrival in Kathmandu – Welcome to the Himalayan Capital: As your flight descends into the Kathmandu Valley, the distant silhouette of snow-capped Himalayan peaks greets you. Upon arrival at Tribhuvan International Airport, our representative meets you with a warm Nepali welcome before escorting you to your hotel. After settling in, enjoy a leisurely afternoon to rest or take a gentle stroll through the vibrant streets nearby. Overnight in Kathmandu.

Kathmandu Durbar Square & Patan – A Journey Through Time: After breakfast at your hotel. Today’s exploration begins at Kathmandu Durbar Square, once the royal palace of the Malla and Shah kings. Wander through historic courtyards, intricately carved wooden temples, and visit the sacred Kumari Ghar, home of the Living Goddess. Next, ascend to Swayambhunath Stupa, perched atop a hill and offering sweeping panoramas of the Kathmandu Valley below. Prayer flags dance gently in the breeze as monks circle the stupa chanting mantras. In the afternoon, travel to the ancient city of Patan, renowned for its artistic heritage. Explore Patan Durbar Square, the stone-carved Krishna Temple, and the golden courtyards of Hiranya Varna Mahavihar. Overnight in Kathmandu.

Sacred Temples & Medieval Bhaktapur – Spiritual and Cultural Immersion: After breakfast, begin your day at Pashupatinath Temple, Nepal’s most sacred Hindu shrine situated beside the holy Bagmati River. Witness the spiritual rituals that unfold daily along the cremation ghats. Continue to the massive Boudhanath Stupa, a spiritual center for Tibetan Buddhism. Circumambulate the stupa alongside monks and pilgrims as prayer wheels spin continuously around you. Later, drive to Bhaktapur, the best-preserved medieval city in the valley. Here, time seems to stand still as you wander through cobblestone streets lined with pottery makers, traditional woodcarvers, and pagoda-style temples. Overnight in Kathmandu.

Flight to Paro & Transfer to Thimphu – Entering the Kingdom of Bhutan: This morning, board your mountain flight to Bhutan. On a clear day, the journey reveals stunning Himalayan giants—Jumolhari, Kanchenjunga, and more. Upon landing in Paro, your Bhutanese guide welcomes you to the Land of the Thunder Dragon. If time permits, visit the serene Kyichu Lhakhang, one of the country’s oldest temples, followed by a stop at Paro Dzong, an impressive fortress overlooking the Paro River. Drive onward to the capital city, Thimphu, set amidst forested hills and crisp mountain air. Overnight in Thimphu.

Thimphu Sightseeing & Drive to Punakha – Culture, Crafts & Himalayan Vistas: Spend the morning discovering Bhutan’s unique cultural treasures, including the Memorial Chorten, the National Library, the Nunnery, and the Folk Heritage Museum. Learn about traditional paper-making and visit the School of Arts & Crafts (Zorig Chusum) where young Bhutanese train in the 13 classical arts of Bhutan. Browse local handicraft centers before leaving Thimphu. In the afternoon, travel toward the warmer valleys of Punakha, stopping at the spectacular Dochu La Pass (3,100m) for tea and breathtaking mountain views. Overnight in Punakha.

Punakha Dzong & Excursion to Gangtey – Valleys, Monasteries & Black-Necked Cranes: After breakfast, visit the majestic Punakha Dzong, strategically located at the confluence of the Pho Chu and Mo Chu rivers. Known for its beautiful architecture, it symbolizes Bhutan’s religious and administrative history. Then drive to the wide glacial basin of Phobjikha Valley (Gangtey), a quiet and pristine landscape. This serene valley is the winter home of the rare Black-necked Cranes. Explore the surroundings and visit the Gangtey Monastery, the region’s only Nyingmapa monastery. In the evening, continue to Wangdue for your overnight stay. Overnight in Wangdue.

Wangdue to Paro – Museums, Dzongs & Mountain Legends: Today, drive along winding roads back to Paro. In the afternoon, visit the National Museum (Ta Dzong), home to rare artifacts, thangkas, and ancient armor. Descend to explore Paro Dzong, an architectural masterpiece linked by a traditional wooden bridge. Visit Drukgyel Dzong, once strategically important against Tibetan forces, offering impressive views of Mount Jumolhari on clear days. End the day with a visit to a typical Bhutanese farmhouse for a glimpse of traditional rural life. Overnight in Paro.

Hike to Taktsang (Tiger’s Nest) – Bhutan’s Iconic Monastery: This morning marks a highlight of your Bhutan journey. After breakfast, begin your hike to the legendary Taktsang Monastery (Tiger’s Nest). Perched dramatically on a cliff nearly 900 meters above the valley floor, the monastery offers awe-inspiring views and a deep sense of spirituality. Spend time absorbing the serene atmosphere before descending for lunch. The rest of the day is open for remaining sightseeing or relaxation. Overnight in Paro.

Fly Back to Kathmandu – Evening farewell dinner: After breakfast, transfer to Paro Airport for your return flight to Kathmandu. Upon arrival, you will be met and driven to your hotel. The afternoon is free - perfect for souvenir shopping, café hopping. Evening farewell dinner with live Nepali cultural performance before your final departure. Overnight in Kathmandu.
Kathmandu/Departure Free till departure. Departure Transfer to airport to connect onward flight.

generalInfo:
Be among the first ones to visit this hidden in the Himalayas country and see how Bhutanese protect their culture and environment. Finally, after 2 years of isolation, the mystical Kingdom of Bhutan reopened its borders to international travellers.

On this 5 day tour, we will visit major cities such as Paro, Thimphu and Punakha. It is a perfect destination to do some spiritual searching and to connect with the greater aspects of the world being. What do you know about life in a monastery or a life of a monk? Why were temples built on top of the peaks? What's karma? Why meditate?

One of the memories you will carry - we will witness a Black-Necked Crane Festival in Thimphu. The festival is an occasion for the locals to rejoice and celebrate the arrival of this endangered and majestic bird which becomes an inseparable part of their daily lives during the winter months.

We will explore the most important dzongs and dive into the history of Buddhism. While doing that we will interact with locals, try new food, see how life goes, what villagers do, how women run households and treat you as royals.

dayInfo.description: The flight to Paro is one of the most spectacular mountain flights in the world, providing a spectacular panorama of some of the highest mountains on earth. After lunch, we will enjoy sightseeing at Paro, visiting the Ta Dzong Museum which shelters a lot of religious relics, works of art and handicrafts providing great insight on Bhutan’s historical, cultural, and religious past. Next, we visit the Rimpong Dzong and observe the painting of the great saint Milarepa, considered the master of meditation by the Bhutanese. Afterwards, we drive to the capital, Thimphu along the Pachu River. Overnight in Thimphu

From Thimpu, a scenic drive takes us to Punakha over Dochu La (3,200 m). At Punakha, we visit Punakha Dzong, also known as Pungtang DechenPhotrang Dzong (meaning “the palace of great happiness or bliss”). Observing the administrative and cultural centre for a while, we advance towards Chimi Lhakhang en route to Wangdiphodrang (Dzong was built in 1638). After spending some time there, we drive back to Thimphu for overnight.

We spend our day touring around Thimphu. At first, we visit the Memorial Chorten that was built in honour of the third King Jigme Dorji Wangchuck then Cheri monastery and Tashichho Dzong (Fortress of the Glorious Religion). Then we of course will visit Changangkha Lhakhang, a place you cannot avoid when in Bhutan. Located on a river bank, it is a monastery that will steal your heart. After our tour around the city, we drive to Paro to spend the night.

After breakfast, we hike towards the Taktsang Monastery which takes about 3 -4 hrs to reach there. The Monastery is an important pilgrim site for the Buddhists. As per the legends, the great Guru Rimpoche and his consort meditated in a cave here for three months after he brought the teachings of the Buddhist Dharma to Bhutan in the 8th Century. After meditation, they turned themselves in the forms of Guru Dorji Drolo and a tigress to defeat the demons in the valley below. The cave, where the monastery was later built is thought to be the origin of Buddhism in Bhutan. In the afternoon, we drive to the ruins of the 17th Century Drukgyel Dzong, an historic monument built by the Shabdrung to commemorate his victory over Tibetans in 1644. We then return to Paro and visit 7th Century Kyichu Lhakhang, one of the 108 temples constructed by the Tibetan king Songtsen Gampo. And then back to the hotel to rest.
Until next! We will take you to the airport for your flight right after breakfast.

placesVisited: Paro, Thimphu, Dochu-La pass, Phobjikha Valley/ Gangtey, Phobjikha Sanctuary, Black necked cranes (Nov to March), Punakha, Chimi Lhakhang, Taktsang Monastery
generalInfo:
Bhutan cultural holiday is a tailor-made holiday that follows the itinerary below, but
of course, this can be adapted to suit your interests. This carefully crafted itinerary
covers Bhutan’s western valleys, taking in the spectacular Himalayan and lowland
landscapes and the culture and lifestyles of the people living here.

Traveling with your English-speaking driver, and guide, you will drive over mountain
passes, and through exquisite elevated landscapes, while also seeing the ever-
changing ecosystems that Bhutan has to offer. The natural highlight of the itinerary is
Phobjikha Valley, also known as Gangtey, which is most famous for being home to
hundreds of black-necked cranes that swoop in between November and March. It is
also home to various wildlife including Himalayan black bears and sambar.

This trip starts in Paro, where your flight lands, with time to explore its Rinpung Dzong
Fortress and Ta Dzong Museum before heading on to Thimphu, the capital of Bhutan.
Here you have a full day to take in its many cultural sites including the National
Memorial Chorten, Changangkha Temple, and Drubthob Monastery.

After driving over the Dochu-La pass (3,100m), with great views over Bhutan’s
Himalayas, you have time in the balmy Phobjikha Valley, visiting its eponymous
sanctuary and also Gangtey Gompa Monastery. From here we head to Punakha, which
is known as Bhutan’s winter capital as it is less elevated than Thimphu. Cultural greats
here include Punakha Dzong, the second largest dzong in the country. You will have a
whole day to discover this “Palace of Great Happiness”.

Your final stop is back in Paro, which we can use as a base for exploring one more
superb cultural site: the great Taktsang Monastery, otherwise known as Tiger’s Nest
Monastery. This magnificent, sacred site is the highlight of the tour for many people and
is considered the origin of Buddhism in Bhutan.

dayInfo.description: The flight to Paro is one of the most spectacular mountain flights in the world, with a constantly changing panorama of some of the highest mountains on earth. Our World Tour Plan representative will meet you at Paro airport exit doors following customs formalities. After lunch enjoy afternoon sightseeing around Paro, including a visit to the Ta Dzong Museum housing many religious relics, works of art, and handicrafts offering a great orientation into Bhutan’s historical, cultural, and religious past. Next, visit the Rinpung Dzong to see the painting of the great saint Milarepa, considered the master of meditation by the Bhutanese and believed to have attained enlightenment in a lifetime. Dzong’s are large monasteries and district administrative centers, which were once strategic forts. Afterwards, drive to the capital, Thimphu (1.5 hours) following the Pachu River. Overnight at your hotel in Thimphu.

Once a rustic village sitting in a broad, fertile river valley, Thimphu is today the nation’s bustling capital. Enjoy a full day of sightseeing, including a visit to the National Memorial Chorten depicting the Buddhist faith in the form of paintings and statues. This temple was first initiated by the Third King as a protection from the negative elements of modernization and as a monument to world peace. The Royal Queen Mother completed it as a memorial stupa for the Third King who passed away in 1972. Continue to the 12th-century Changangkha Temple and Drubthob monastery housing the Zilukha Nunnery. Other sites to visit include the School for Arts and Crafts where students are taught the 13 types of Bhutanese art, The National Library housing the collection of Bhutanese scriptures dating back to the 8th century, the Traditional Paper Factory displaying the Bhutanese paper-making process, and a fascinating replica of a medieval farmhouse at the Folk Heritage Museum. If there is time, you may visit the nursing pen for the Takin, the national animal of Bhutan, and Tashichhodzong, ‘the fortress of the glorious religion’. Initially erected in 1641 by Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal, it was rebuilt in the 1960s during the reign of Bhutan’s third king in the traditional style, without plans or nails. Tashichhodzong houses some ministries, His Majesty’s secretariat, and the central monk body. You can visit Thimphu Market to see the variety of food of Bhutan, including basket upon basket of fiery chilies, fresh cheese, and a variety of fresh greens. In addition, many stalls contain Bhutanese handicrafts and household items. Overnight at your hotel in Thimphu.

Transfer to Phobjikha Valley (5.5-6 hours). Drive over the Dochu-La pass (3,100 meters) which on a clear day offers an incredible view of Himalayan peaks before descending into balmy Punakha valley (about 3 hours total driving time). The drive through the countryside affords a glimpse of everyday life in this most remote of Himalayan kingdoms. In the Dochu-La area, there are vast rhododendron forests that grow to tree size and bloom in late April/early May covering the mountains in a riot of glorious spring color. Continue through the bustling market town of Wangduephodrang, driving up a winding mountain road through oak and rhododendron forests, and over a high pass down into the wide and picturesque Phobjikha Valley. Phobjikha is one of Bhutan’s few glacial valleys, and chosen winter home of black-necked cranes (November – March) migrating from the Tibetan plateau. The valley is one of the most beautiful in Bhutan. Overnight at your hotel in Phobjikha.

Spend the day exploring the Phobjikha Valley, including a visit to the Phobjikha Sanctuary with an opportunity to view the majestic black-necked cranes (Nov-Mar only) and Gangtey Monastery, dating back to the 16th century and the only Nyingmapa monastery in western Bhutan. In the afternoon enjoy one of the many walks available traversing the stunning surroundings of this spacious valley. Overnight at your hotel in Phobjikha.

After breakfast drive to Punakha. On arrival, visit Punakha Dzong, the “Palace of Great Happiness” built in 1637 by the Zhabdrung, the ‘Unifier of Bhutan’ as predicted by the great Guru Rinpoche (Padmasambhava). It is situated at the confluence of the Pho Chu and Mo Chu (Male and Female Rivers) and is the winter headquarters of the Je Khenpo and hundreds of monks who move from Thimphu to this warmer location. The three-storey main temple of the Punakha Dzong is a breathtaking example of traditional architecture with four intricately embossed entrance pillars crafted from cypress and decorated in gold and silver. It was here in 1907 that Bhutan’s first king was crowned. Overnight at your hotel in Punakha

Enjoy a walk to Chimi Lhakhang, the temple of the Drukpa Kuenley who is also known as the Divine Madman. He inherited the Divine Madman title when he revolted against orthodox Buddhism in his time. He taught the people that religion is an inner feeling and one doesn’t need to be an ordained monk. He is also considered a symbol of fertility and most childless couples go to his temple for blessing. Afterwards, drive back to Thimphu where you will have an opportunity to visit handicraft and souvenir stores. Afterwards, proceed to Paro. Overnight at your hotel in Paro.

After breakfast hike to Taktsang Monastery. The trail is broad and the walk of approximately 1.5 to 2 hours uphill takes you almost a kilometer above the Paro Valley. Note: Two hours for those who are physically fit and for amateurs it will take five to seven hours both ways. However, there are horse services available at the base of Taktshang monastery, you will have to pay approximately $35 one way. A horse will reach you till the prayer wheel The view of Taktsang Monastery built on a sheer cliff face 900 meters above the valley floor is a spectacular sight. The Monastery is also an important pilgrim site for the Buddhists. The great Guru Rinpoche is said to have flown here on the back of a tigress (Yeshey Tshogyal) when he brought the teachings of the Buddhist Dharma to Bhutan in the 8th Century. He meditated in the cave for 3 years, 3 months, 3 weeks, and 3 days before subjugating the malicious spirits, and concealing profound treasures for the benefit of sentient beings and where the monastery was later built. The cave is said to be the origin of Buddhism in Bhutan. Nearby there is a cafeteria where you can stop for refreshments before returning to Paro for lunch or you can choose to eat there. In the afternoon drive to Drukgyel Dzong, which is located in the upper Paro Valley. Unlike other Dzongs built by Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal and his successors, Drukgyel Dzong was served solely for defensive purposes without administrative and religious functions, especially against external threats from the border. Drukgyel dzong was built to commemorate his victory against invading Tibetans in 1644. In fine weather, the towering peak of the sacred Mount Jomolhari (7314m) appears as a stunning backdrop. On the return drive to Paro, visit 7th Century Kyichu Lhakhang, one of the 108 temples constructed by the Tibetan king Songtsen Gampo. Kyichu is built like the Jokhang in Lhasa. Inside there is a great golden image of Buddha Shakyamuni. Alternatively, day 7 could be spent on a day trip to the Haa Valley, one of the most Unlike other Dzongs built by Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyal and his successors, Drukgyel Dzong was served solely for defensive purposes without administrative and religious functions, especially against external threats from the border. picturesque districts in Bhutan. Reached via the beautiful Chelela Pass, Haa Valley is characterized by its surrounding rugged and mountainous terrain. Overnight at your hotel in Paro.
Breakfast in the hotel, and then drive to the airport for a flight to your onward destination

tourName: Bhutan cultural tour, history of Bhutan
placesVisited: Paro, Tiger’s Nest Monastery, Thimphu, Punakha, Punakha Dromchoe Festival
generalInfo:
This Bhutan cultural tour will, in little over a week, showcase the enthralling history and nature of the small and once-isolated Kingdom of Bhutan. What would Bhutan be without it's magnificent nature walks and Himalayan trails? We offer an array of varied walking trail experiences beginning with the breathtakingly high altitude perch of the Tiger's Nest Monastery above the Paro Valley floor. With a gourmet picnic lunch en-route, this is the perfect way to savour this stunning location and the panoramic experience of this walk.

We'll also take you through a protected National Park, noted to be one of the Kingdom's largest protected reserves. A trail that leads up to the secluded and serene Cheri Goemba passes through forests of broad leaved oak, rhododendron, walnut and maple and is a verdant home of varied and a rich bird-life.

We weave rich cultural experiences through this maze of nature and history with experiences that involve interactions with local art, craft and local cuisine. With Thimphu claiming the title of Bhutan's largest urban settlement, we take advantage of this setting to let you delve into authentic local cuisine with a full course sit-down Bhutanese meal and an interactive experience at the local painting school.

There's also an opportunity to see the unique Punakha Dromchoe - the staging ground for a historic battle that took place between the invading Tibetans and local Bhutanese, who were guarding an important religious relic. This remarkable reenactment of history goes on display once a year with the beautiful backdrop of the Punakha Dzong, situated at the confluence of two Himalayan rivers that pass around it. The two-day dance festival is a riot of colour, unique face-masks and dancing monks; all enjoyed by the locals who throng to the Dzong to witness this spectacle.


So come with us on this amazing discovery of such a rich culture, hidden in the mysterious mountains of this secluded Himalayan Kingdom.

dayInfo.description: An Afternoon in Paro – You fly into Paro after a spectacular flight in through the Himalayas to spend the afternoon exploring the spectacular ruins of Drukyel Dzong and the collective pieces of history that define this Kingdom at the Paro Museum. You end the day with a very traditional and extremely relaxing Hot Stone Massage!

The Tiger’s Nest – The day begins with this dramatic ascent to the Taktsang or the historic Tiger’s Nest Monastery. Once there we’ll walk you through the mythology and history behind this stunning cliff-side monastery in the mountains. A gourmet picnic lunch is the perfect way to cap this walk for the day with an evening of leisure back in Paro.
Flight home – You return home from Paro, the way you came through the Himalayan mountains.

tourName: Bhutan cultural tour, Land of the Thunder Dragon
placesVisited: Thimpu (Late King's Memorial Chorten, Handicraft emporium etc), Dochu La, Punakha, Punakha Dzong, Gangtey (Gangtey Monastery, Black Neck Cranes viewing), Phobjikha valley, Wangdiphodrang, Bhutan's national museum, Rinpung Dzong, Bhutanese farmhouse visit, Hike to Taksang (Tiger’s Nest Monastery)
generalInfo:
Traditional culture thrives in Bhutan and on this relaxed small group tour you will have a whole week to explore the most secretive of the Himalayan kingdoms.

Visual richness is plentiful – in everything from the art, craft and architecture to the panoramic mountain views and colourful rhodendron valleys. On this Bhutan cultural tour we have combined a carefully balanced mix of hikes, mountain drives and pristine landscapes with visits to cities, monasteries, dzhongs, craft workshops and even a local farmhouse.

You’ll start your tour in the capital Thimpu where you’ll see the traditional, the religious and the modern are learning co-exist. There may now be cars on the roads but it still retains its relaxed, small town feel. You’ll get a real understanding of how beauty has motivated creativity here as a local guide takes you to visit paper factories, the folk museum, gold and silver workshops, textile centres and Zo Rig Chusum – where young students study 'the thirteen crafts'.

You’ll then head onward to Punakha, Bhutan’s former capital and home to one of its most beautiful Dzongs before setting off into its vast protected natural areas in search of glacial valleys, hill top monasteries, black necked crane gatherings and Bhutanese national treasures housed in a former watch factory.

No trip to Bhutan would be complete without a hike up to its most iconic monastery, the Taktsang or ‘Tiger’s nest’. Perched 900 meters above the beautiful Paro valley, it is more than worth the uphill climb into the clouds as the spectacular views will attest.

Each Group Size: 3 - 12 Adults

dayInfo.description: Paro Arrival, During the flight, on a clear day, you can see breathtaking views of the Himalaya Mountains, including the sacred Jumolhari and Jichu Drake Peaks in Bhutan. On arrival you will be greeted by our representative and transferred to your hotel. If time permit in the afternoon you can visit the Kyichu Lhakhang and Paro Dzong. In the evening you can drive to the capital town of Thimphu.

Thimpu sightseeing, There are a good many things to see in the capital which has a very relaxed, laid-back feel about it. Thimphu is relatively small having a population of approximately 45,000 people and the streets are wide and tree lined. You will almost certainly visit the Late King's Memorial Chorten, the National Library, Drubthob Nunnery, Folk Heritage Museum, the handmade paper factory, the school of arts and crafts where young students learn the traditional arts and crafts (Zo Rig Chusum – the thirteen crafts), Gold and the Silver Smiths workshop, Zangtopelri Lhakhang, and the Handicraft Emporium and the local handicraft centers to see the weavers at work and also varieties of textiles, thangkha paintings, masks, jewellery etc

Thimpu / Punakha (1250m.) 3-4 hrs. drive, After breakfast you will drive to Punakha, with a stop en route for tea at Dochu La (3,100 meters), where on a clear day you can get spectacular views of the Himalayas. After lunch at Wangduephodrong continue to drive to Punakha, the former capital of Bhutan, and visit Punakha Dzong, which is noteworthy both for being one of the most beautiful dzongs in Bhutan and also for having been built by the first Shabdrung in 1636.

Excursion to Gangtey (2890m.) / Wangdiphodrang (1460m.) – 5-6 hrs. drive, Visit Gangety (Phobjikha) Is one of the few flacial valleys in Bhutan and chosen home for Black Neck Cranes Which migrate from the central Asiatic Plateau to escape its harsh winters. Explore Phobjikha valley and also visit to Gangtey Monastery the only Nyingmapa monastery in Bhutan. Evening you will return to Wangdiphodrang for overnight stay.

Wangdiphodrang / Paro (2260m.) - 3-4 hrs. drive, Today we drive along the winding mountain road to Paro. Afternoon, tour of Bhutan's national museum, a fascinating place housed in an old watchtower above the huge Paro Dzong (monastery/fortress). The museum holds a fantastic collection of Bhutanese national treasures ranging from ancient armour to textiles and thangkha paintings. Then, we drive to the head of the valley and visit Drukgyel Dzong built in a location that was chosen for its control over the route to Tibet. A spectacular view of Mount. Jumolhari (23,996ft /7314m) can be seen from here. Also visit Rinpung Dzong and a typical Bhutanese farm house.

Paro - hike to Taksang (Tiger’s Nest Monastery), After breakfast hike to Taktsang (Tiger’s Nest) Monastery, which is Bhutan’s most famous monastery. It is perched on the edge of a steep cliff, about 900 meters above Paro Valley. The hike to reach the viewpoint to the monastery makes for a nice half-day excursion. After lunch you can visit other important site which you could not complete previous days.
Departure. Transfer to airport. Fly back to Kathmandu or Bangkok.

placesVisited: Paro, Thimphu, Wangduephodrang, Wangdue Dzong ruins, Phobjikha Valley or Gangtey, Black necked cranes, Trongsa, Bumthang : Chumey, Choekhor, Tang and Ur Valleys, Chamkhar, Taktsang or Tiger’s Nest Monastery
generalInfo:
An eleven-day cultural tour of Bhutan that encompasses the best of the country,natural and cultural heritage. This customized vacation to Bhutan, which includes your driver and guide who speaks English, follows the itinerary below to fit your schedule and interests. All we want is to make it easier for you to discover Bhutan's various temples, museums, and monasteries, as well as its varied landscapes in the western valleys.
Starting in Paro, you have time to take in the sites here such as Rinpung Dzong
Fortress and Ta Dzong Museum, and then head onto the capital city of Thimphu. Spend a couple of days in and around Thimphu with visits to Simtokha Dzong, the oldest fortress of the Kingdom, King's Memorial Chorten, and Tashichhodzong Monastery.

We then head out of town and over high mountain passes, with views of the Himalayas,into the Phobjikha Valley, also known as Gangtey, a stunning glacial valley with rhododendron-covered slopes and pine forests. En route we stop at Wangduephodrang to visit the splendid Wangdue Dzong as well as its traditional market. The Valley itself is famous for its black-necked cranes which come in great numbers between November and March, but is also home to a wide variety of other wildlife.
Our next stop is following another magnificent drive across the 3,300m high Pele La Pass to Trongsa. This is home to the famous Trongsa Dzong, the ancestral home of the Royal Family. Equally striking is Bumthang, the name given to the collection of four valleys of Chumey, Choekhor, Tang, and Ura and home to some of Bhutan’s oldest temples and monasteries. These include Kurje Lhakhang and Jambay Lhakhang.

Heading back to Thimphu and then Paro as our final stop, we take a day to explore one of Bhutan’s most spectacular sites: Taktsang Monastery which is considered the birthplace of Bhutan Buddhism. And, we hope, a fitting finale to this Bhutan holiday. As well as these cultural and natural highlights, we will also ensure that you will spend plenty of time with local people, enjoying traditional food, visiting markets, learning about Bhutanese lifestyles, and so on.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Paro- A flight to Bhutan is one of the most spectacular in the entire Himalayas. Whether flying along the Himalayan range from Nepal or over the foothills from India, each flight is a mesmerizing aeronautical feat and offers an exciting descent into the Kingdom. After Immigration and customs formalities, you will be received by our representative. Transfer to the hotel. In the evening take a stroll around the town's main street. Overnight at the hotel in Paro.

Paro Sightseeing: After breakfast, visit Ta Dzong (National Museum) and then walk down the trail to visit Rinpung Dzong which has a long and fascinating history. Afternoon, visit Drukgyel Dzong, the fortress from where Bhutanese repelled several invasions by Tibetan armies. In the evening, visit Kichu Lhakhang, one of the oldest and most sacred shrines of the Kingdom. Overnight at the hotel in Paro.

Paro - Thimphu (60 km, 2 hours): After breakfast proceed to Thimphu, the capital town of Bhutan. On the way visit Tacho Lhakhang. Tachogang, also known as Tachog Lhakhang, which translates to Temple of the Hill of the Excellent Horse,was constructed by Thangtong Gyalpo, the renowned Great Iron Bridge Builder (1385-1464). It is said that one day while meditating at the same location, Thangtong Gyalpo saw the spiritual horse Balaha, an incarnation of Chenrezig Avalokiteshvara, and was moved to construct a temple. Thus, the temple was called the "Temple of the Excellent Horse, or Tachogang Lhakhang. En route stop at Chuzom (confluence) where Paro river meets Thimphu river. Nearby Thimphu, visit Simtokha Dzong, the oldest fortress of the Kingdom which now houses the School for Buddhist Studies. Afternoon, in Thimphu, visit King's Memorial Chorten and Tashichhodzong, a beautiful medieval fortress/monastery, later visit Handicrafts Emporium, and Textile and Simply Bhutan followed by a visit local market. Overnight at the hotel in Thimphu.

Thimphu - Punakha (75 km, 2 hours): Morning, Thimphu sightseeing, visiting the National Library, Painting School, and Traditional Medicine Institute. After lunch, drive to Punakha, the old capital of Bhutan. Stop en route at Dochula Pass (3,050m) which heralds the most enchanting views of Bhutan. On arrival, check into the hotel. Evening visits Punakha Dzong, the fortress of the 17th century and later visit to Khamsum Yulley Namgyal Chorten. Overnight at the hotel in Punakha.

Punakha - Wangduephodrang - Gangtey (70 km, 3 hours): After breakfast drive to Gangtey via Wangduephodrang. Visit the ruins of Wangdue Dzong and interesting local market. Further ahead pass through dense forests and oak, rhododendron trees, reaching at Gangtey .Evening take a walk around Gangtey village and visit Gangtey Gompa, the only Nyingmapa monastery in this region. (Overnight at the hotel in Gangtey.)

Gangtey - Trongsa (120 km, 4 hours): Morning explore Phobjikha Valley which is famous for Black Necked Cranes. The cranes migrate here from the High Tibetan plateau to escape its harsh winter. After lunch drive to Trongsa crossing 3,300m high Pele La Pass. Evening visit to Trongsa Market. (Overnight at the hotel in Trongsa.)

Trongsa - Bumthang (68 km, 3 hours): Morning visit to Trongsa Dzong, the masterpiece of Bhutanese architecture, and Ta Dzong, the watch tower that was built to oversee the ongoing construction of the Trongsa Dzong and also to watch out for any invading forces. After lunch, proceed to Bumthang, the religious heartland of the nation. Evening at leisure. Dinner and overnight in Bumthang Hotel.

Bumthang Sightseeing: Bumthang is the general name given to the combination of four valleys - Chumey, Choekhor, Tang, and Ura with altitudes varying from 2,600m to 4,000m. It is home to many prominent Buddhist temples and monasteries. Visit Tamshing Lhakhang, the treasure house of interesting religious Buddhist paintings. Then visit Jakar Dzong, the administrative center of the valley. Afternoon visits Kurje Lhakhang, one of the most sacred places.
